title: How to Edit Text in Figma: Adding Text, Text Styles, and More

steps.title: Click the Text tool.
steps.content: Click the Text tool. This is the T button at the bottom of the Figma page. Anytime you want to change something about the text you're working with, you'll start by selecting this tool. Another quick way to open the Text tool is to press the T key on your keyboard. All text in Figma, like other objects, is created on layers. You'll see all text layers in the Layers panel on the left side of Figma, prefaced with a "T" icon.

steps.title: Hover your mouse cursor over the text you want to edit.
steps.content: Hover your mouse cursor over the text you want to edit. If the text is editable, a blue line appears under it. While your mouse is over the text, the pointer will turn into a vertical cursor.

steps.title: Select the text you want to edit.
steps.content: Select the text you want to edit. You can do this by clicking and dragging the cursor over the text to highlight it in blue. When text is selected, its properties will appear in the Text properties panel on the right. [1] X Research source If you don't want to change the look of the text but instead want to add, delete, or correct something, click the cursor to place it at the desired position instead. Now you can modify it as needed. You can also select the text by clicking the text layer in the Layers panel on the left. Additionally, if you want to change the look of multiple text layers at once, you can hold down the Shift key as you select multiple text layers.

steps.title: Find out if a Text Style is applied to this text.
steps.content: Find out if a Text Style is applied to this text. If you see a panel called "Text" in the right sidebar when text is selected, there are no Text Styles applied to the selection. But if you don't see a "Text" panel and do see one called "Ag," this means there's a text style applied to that text overriding your ability to make changes. See Using Text Styles for more information on Text Styles.

steps.title: Change the look of the text.
steps.content: Change the look of the text. While the text or text layer is selected, the size, alignment, font face, and other options you choose in the Text panel will be applied to the text. [2] X Research source Use the Stroke panel to add an outline (or inner line) to your text and adjust its size and color. The Effects panel lets you add text effects like drop shadow, inner shadow, and blurring. If the Text panel is grayed out and you see a yellow icon with "A?" next to the font's name, the font is not installed on your computer. [3] X Research source You can't edit the text unless you install the missing font or choose a replacement. To choose a replacement font, click the A? to open the Missing Fonts screen, and then select a font you have installed.

steps.title: Change text color.
steps.content: Change text color. The color of text is actually controlled by the Fill panel in the right sidebar, not on the Text panel. Clicking the desired color in the Fill panel will recolor the selected text.

steps.title: Move text around.
steps.content: Move text around. When you move text in Figma, all text on that text layer will move. Here's how to move text: Press the V key on the keyboard to select the Move tool. Click the text on the page, or choose it from the Layers panel. This surrounds the text with a bounding box. Click and drag the text to the desired position.

steps.title: Resize text with the Scale tool.
steps.content: Resize text with the Scale tool. Figma recommends only changing the size of text using the Text panel, but you can also resize text with the scaling tool. The difference is that the text size may change to a different size than other text in your presentation, so things may not be as uniform. Still, this is handy if you're working with text that you need to resize to fit in a certain area. Here's how to scale text: [4] X Research source Press the K key on the keyboard to open the Scale tool. Click the text on the page, or click the text layer in the Layers panel on the left. Drag any of the corner bounding boxes on the text outward to make it bigger, or inward to make it smaller.

steps.title: Click the Text tool.
steps.content: Click the Text tool. This is the T button at the bottom of the Figma page. Anytime you want to change something about the text you're working with, you'll start by selecting this tool.

steps.title: Choose how to create a new text layer.
steps.content: Choose how to create a new text layer. When you add text to Figma, you're adding a new layer containing that text. There are two ways to create a text layer: [5] X Research source One is to click the location where you want to add text. This creates a new text layer with text resizing set to Auto Width, which means that as you type, the width of the text box expands as you enter more text. The other is to click and drag your mouse to draw a text box with the desired dimensions. This not only defines the size of the text layer before you start typing, but also sets the text resizing to Fixed Width, which lets you enter more text. It also automatically wraps the text so it overflows onto the next line.

steps.title: Start typing.
steps.content: Start typing. Whether you clicked the mouse at the desired location or draw a text box, a cursor will appear and you can start typing. You'll have some generic font settings by default—a smallish black font—but you change it by selecting it and using the Text panel in the right sidebar , or by creating or applying a text style . Your text layers appear in the Layers panel with a "T" before them.

steps.title: Select some text that has properties you want to use.
steps.content: Select some text that has properties you want to use. Text Styles allow you to define properties for text that you can use in any of your team's projects. Once you've customized an area of text to your liking, click the name of the text layer in the Layers panel so you can create a style from it. [6] X Research source For example, if you're designing a website and want all section headers to be 36pt and right aligned, you can create a Header style with those properties and apply it to every header on your website. When you make changes to a Text Style's properties later, such as its typeface, alignment, or spacing, the changes will affect all text to which you've applied that style. This is a great way to quickly change text across your entire design without tediously editing multiple text layers separately. Text Styles do not include color. You can add color using the Fill panel, or by creating a Color Style, which we'll get to later.

steps.title: Click the Style icon by the Typography heading.
steps.content: Click the Style icon by the Typography heading. The icon looks like 4 dots arranged in a square.

steps.title: Click the + on the Text Styles window.
steps.content: Click the + on the Text Styles window. It's at the top-right corner. This opens the "Create new text style" window.

steps.title: Type a name and click Create style.
steps.content: Type a name and click Create style . This creates a new style using the properties of the selected text. Give the style a name that's reflective of the content you're applying the style to (such as "body" or "links"), or descriptive of the style itself (such as "red header").

steps.title: Assign a Text Style to other text.
steps.content: Assign a Text Style to other text. Now that you've created a Text Style, you can apply it to any text layers in your project. Here's how: [7] X Research source Select the layer(s) you want to apply the style to on the page or in the Layers panel. To select multiple layers, hold down the ⇧ Shift key as you click each layer's name. Click the four dots at the top-right corner of the Typography section in the right sidebar. Click the name of the Text Style to apply it. When you try to modify text that has a style applied to it, you won't see a Text panel on the right—you'll just see "Ag" and the style's name.

steps.title: Remove a Text Style from text.
steps.content: Remove a Text Style from text. If there's a style applied to text that you'd rather just edit separately, or you just want to assign the text a different style, you can easily unlink the Text Style from the text. Here's how: Select the layer(s) from which you want to remove the style on the page or in the Layers panel. Hover your mouse cursor over the name of the Text Style on the "Ag" panel in the right sidebar. You'll see a small link icon appear. Click the link icon to unlink the style from the text. The Text panel will then reappear in the right sidebar so you can edit the text separately.

steps.title: Change the properties of a Text Style.
steps.content: Change the properties of a Text Style. When you change something about a Text Style that's applied to text in your project (such as its size or color), those changes will affect all text with that style. Here's how you can make changes: [8] X Research source Hover your mouse cursor over the style's name in the right-hand sidebar under Text styles . Click the icon of two dials that appears when you hover the style. Edit the font family, weight, size, line spacing, and kerning as desired under the Properties header. Click the horizontal three dots in the bottom-right corner to add even more properties to your Text Style.

steps.title: Create a Color Style.
steps.content: Create a Color Style. Because Text Styles don't include color, you might want to create a Color Style to easily apply to styles that correspond with Text Styles. The process is similar to creating a Text Style: Select some text and choose a color from the Fill panel. Click the Style icon on the Fill panel (the four dots). Click the + to create a new style. Type a name for the style, such as its color, and click Create style . You can now apply that color style to any layer in Figma, including text layers.

steps.title: Share Text and Color Styles to the Team Library.
steps.content: Share Text and Color Styles to the Team Library. If you're part of a team and all working on the same document, you can publish your styles so they are available to your team. Here's how: Click the Assets tab in the left sidebar. Click the Library icon (the open book) at the top. Click Publish . Type a description of the changes you're making, such as "Adding header style," for the version history. Click the down arrow next to "Styles and components" to view and select styles to publish. Click Publish this file . Anyone working on the project in Figma will be prompted to receive the update.
